metadata.title: TensorFlow Image Recognition Tutorial using Serverless Architecture — Node JS | by Prabhu | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: TensorFlow Image Recognition Tutorial using Serverless Architecture — Node JS
metadata.description: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based architectures such as VGG-16, GoogLeNet, ResNet, MobileNet, etc., are widely used models for image recognition, object detections from images and videos. For…

all_paragraphs: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based architectures such as VGG-16, GoogLeNet, ResNet, MobileNet, etc., are widely used models for image recognition, object detections from images and videos. For more details about convolutional neural network details, please refer to my older blog.

In this blog, I am going to explain the image recognition tutorial using serverless architecture and CNN's MobileNet model. MobileNet architecture is a lightweight model suitable for mobile and embedded devices. The MobileNet model which already trained more than 14 million images and 20,000 image classifications. Using the pre-trained model which helps to classify the input images quickly and produce the results.

Image recognition process using the MobileNet model in serverless cloud functions. Since the MobileNet is lightweight architecture and can run it in cloud functions. In this architecture, we are going to use Node JS for client interface and backend REST service (Serverless).
The above diagram depicts a two-layer architecture.
TensorFlow framework with MobileNet model API wrapper implementation and the API client interface using Node JS stack.
Now, let us see the code layer by layer and step by step.
TensorFlow REST API — Runs in Serverless Environment
First, we will import the TensorFlow node js module. Details are mentioned in the below snippet.
Note:- The source code of both backend REST and client interface developed using Node JS can be found in my Github repo. Please refer to the bottom for the Github link.
The below snippet is the main Node js function which exports as a REST endpoint.
Line 6: The event parameter which contains a body attribute “event.body” gets an image base 64 data comes from the client interface, uploads by user
Line 8: It takes the base 64 image data and writes as an image in a temporary path (for each request, a new file name will be created. Refer, Line 5)

Line 9: It calls another function called “classify” by, passing the parameter path created earlier. The path variable contains the new image file path. The classify function details can be found in the below snippet. The output variable result receives a response in an async mode which contains TensorFlow image prediction results along with probability scores. Please refer to the above Figures 4 & 5 for output details.
Line 5: It reads an image from the path
Line 6: Converts 3 dimensional array from the given image
Line 8: Classify’s image passing the input image’s 3d array matrix as a parameter and gets predicted image results.
Load Mobile net model from URL
Line 7: It submits the input image as base 64 data and post it to the backend REST service endpoint. The variable “apiURL” loads the REST URL from config.json.
Step 1: Download and install/update the Serverless framework in your machine. Refer this Serverless doc link for installation help — https://serverless.com/framework/docs/getting-started/
Once you installed, type “sls — help” should give the output like in the below image
Step 2: Download your AWS Credentials (Access & Secret Key)and set as environment variables in your OS using “export” command if you’re using Linux or Mac OS and “set” command if your OS is windows
Step 3: Clone the source code from the Github URL
After a successful clone, go to the folder serverless_image_tensorflow/backend_api
